text: Sparse Billowy Smoke
Creates thick cloud-like smoke rising from a spherical base.

This shelf tool sets up a sparse pyro simulation of a rising smoke stack, with a meter-scale base. The setup can be used as a starting point for simulating scenarios such as chimney smoke or cooling tower steam.
The shelf tool creates a node network that consists of three components.
smoke_source
takes care of setting up the density and temperature sources that continuously get injected into the simulation. The start of the node chain in this subnetwork (
smoke_base
) defines the shape of the smoke base. You can switch out this node for another geometry object if you'd like to modify the look of the base.
Modify the
Buoyancy Scale
. Increasing its value will make the smoke rise faster, while decreasing it will slow its ascent.
Change how fast the smoke starts to rise
Modify the
Cooling Rate
. Lower values will keep the smoke hot for longer, so that buoyancy force will continue to accelerate it.
Set how fast the rising smoke slows down
Change the
Dissipation
parameter. Higher values will make the smoke rapidly disappear and smaller values will force the smoke to stick around for longer.
Control how fast the smoke disappears
Tweak the
Disturbance
parameter. Higher values will break up the smoke more, while lower values will yield a more smooth-looking result.
Change how much the smoke breaks up
smoke_simulation
contains the DOP network that consumes the sources and carries out the fluid simulation. The parameters on the
sparse pyro solver
have the greatest influence on the emergent shape of the smoke.
smoke_import
subnetwork extracts results of the simulation into a SOP geometry. A
pyro post-process
node sets the proper viewport visualization settings for the smoke and creates a matching render material.
